summary: The fact that people still keep on insisting that Sansa had never bullied Arya and it was all just fun and games, literally...
body: The fact that people still keep on insisting that Sansa had never bullied Arya and it was all just fun and games, literally baffles me. LIKE SHE LITERALLY WISHED FOR ARYA’S DEATH!!! I know that she was upset about Lady’s untimely demise at that time and that she didn’t know better but it still doesn’t change the fact that Sansa bullied Arya. It doesn’t take those experiences away from Arya nor does it take away the insecurities she developed bc of the bullying.

reblog.comment: The fact that people still keep on insisting that Sansa had never bullied Arya and it was all just fun and games, literally baffles me. LIKE SHE LITERALLY WISHED FOR ARYA’S DEATH!!! It doesn’t take those experiences away from Arya nor does it take away the insecurities she developed bc of the bullying.

summary:
Gendry‘s age in the show was just recently noted on the GoT wikia page, it wasn’t there before 🤔
So he‘s three years older than...
body:
Gendry‘s age in the show was just recently noted on the GoT wikia page, it wasn’t there before 🤔

So he‘s three years older than Arya in the show which makes the age difference even smaller than the one in the books which is about 4-5 years. And show!Gendry is also 2 years younger than Jon. Interesting.

summary: I suppose, there were moments is Arya’s childhood, when she tried to dress up like a proper lady  (like her mother), to try how...
caption: I suppose, there were moments is Arya’s childhood, when she tried to dress up like a proper lady (like her mother), to try how it feels - to be a good looking girl in fancy dresses. But it didn’t end up well because of her sister. Young Sansa was a little arrogant piece of shit :D

reblog.comment: I suppose, there were moments is Arya’s childhood, when she tried to dress up like a proper lady (like her mother), to try how it feels - to be a good looking girl in fancy dresses. But it didn’t end up well because of her sister. Young Sansa was a little arrogant piece of shit :D

blog.name: asoiafuniversity
blog.title: ASOIAF University
blog.description:
A collection of metas (critical essays or analysis), gathered from across tumblr, about George R.R. Martin's book series A Song of Ice and Fire (ASOIAF) and its television adaptation Game of Thrones.

For more information about this blog, please read our FAQ.

tags: a song of ice and fire
summary: Stark Sisters as Little Red Riding Hood
title: Stark Sisters as Little Red Riding Hood
body:
ARYA STARK

Arya Meta

  • A brutal critique of fairy tales by Alyssa Rosenberg (March 2014)
  • The Little Red Riding Hood in ASOIAF (mirror link) by ShadowCat Rivers via westeros.org (February 2015) 

Arya as Little Red Riding Hood in other fanworks

  • Red Riding Hood by @sabotensan (August 2012)
  • To Taste Your Beating Heart by PersephoneSyndrome (November 2012)
  • Little Red Riding Hood by @whatcarolthinks (May 2013)
  • You recognise me and other works by @sabotensan (June 2013) 
  • Arya Stark as the Little Red Riding Hood by WeirdSwirl (March 2014)
  • Hey There Little Red Riding Hood by Chash (April 2014)
  • Howl by SashaSilverMoon (June 2014)
  • I think I’ll eat your heart out by @t6ru (July 2014)
  • “For The Red Riding Hood Who Was The Wolf” by Nikita Gill / @meanwhilepoetry (December 2017)

SANSA STARK

Sansa Meta

  • Le Petit Chaperon Rouge and Sansa by @swiftsnowmane (June 2012)
  • Awakening the Beast: Female Sexuality and Empowerment in Sansa’s Arc (mirror link) by brashcandy via westeros.org (November 2012)
  • Sansa’s relationships by @theelliedoll (April 2013)
  • Sansa and Red Riding Hood parallels by @theelliedoll (December 2013)
  • More Fairy Tale References (mirror link) by @sillier-things via asoiafbookgroup (April 2015)
  • Sansa Stark: The Princess in the Tower by @lostlittlesatellites (November 2017)
  • Do you think Sansa will end up at Winterfell by @lady-in-a-song (March 2018)
  • Meta tidbits for the Sansa stans by @tatticstudio55 (November 2018)

Sansa as Little Red Riding Hood in other fanworks

  • Little Red Riding Hood by Freakylady666 (June 2012)
  • Gentle Wolves Should Beware the Woods by whoistorule (September 2012)
  • Into the Wood by Walter Gilman (September 2012)
  • Little Red Riding Bird by zweihand on LJ (December 2013)
  • Running with the Hare and Hunting with the Hound by @kimberlite8 (draft August 2012, illustrated February 2014)
  • Sansa + Red Riding Hood AU by @saintmichaelthearchangel-moved (March 2016)
  • Sansa as Little Red Riding Hood by @jodie-comers (June 2018)

BOTH GIRLS

  • little red riding hood addresses the next wolf by @jonerya (June 2018)

GRRM

  • It’s no surprise that Martin has been fascinated with wolves since childhood. The Stark’s direwolves are central to the plot of both the books and the show. “Well, they’re mythic. I think even as a kid I responded to the werewolf legends and the wolves in the wood and, you know, Little Red Riding Hood and all of that,” says Martin, who claims his choice for the Stark’s direwolf banner came from a gut feeling rather than an attempt at symbolism. –interview with Mashable (November 2014)

If you can think of other ways that Arya and/or Sansa embody Little Red Riding Hood in the books, please feel free to reblog this post and add your own!

summary: Is it just me or in the show s1 they show Arya bullying Sansa way more than vice versa? I am a fan of both of them but have...
question: Is it just me or in the show s1 they show Arya bullying Sansa way more than vice versa? I am a fan of both of them but have noticed they both can get heavily mischaracterized in the show
answer:
I am going to assume you mean the food throwing scene in the first episode. In which, sort of. But real problem is that they changed the actual dynamic of Arya and her role and relationships in the stark family. You can see that in the bow scene as well, with arya shooting the bow and everybody laughing and kind of being supportive? In the books, Catelyn would have been furious and would have dragged her right back to Septa Mordane, and Ned wouldnt be approving at all (despite how much he loves Arya, he is still a traditional man with a traditional mindset and a young noble girl with a bow without permission is a big no no.) This is actually very important because the whole concept is that despite how wild Arya is, it’s not approved by anyone and she is expected to behave in a certain way  and it plays a very important part in her characterisation (her self-consciousness, her feeling of being an outcast, her need to belong, her lack of self-confidence and self-worth). The same thing happens in the food scene. Arya throws food at her old sister, in a feast filled with the noble men and the royal family, during a royal visit and seconds after her sister just spoke with queen, is so unrealistic. It’s supposed to be this sweet family moment where we see Arya being mischievous, and show how everyone finds it funny, but in the books, Arya first wouldnt dare (girl might not be one for rules but she at least tries to behave herself, especially when she knows her butt is going to be handed to her if she doesnt). And Arya really isnt that kind of person. She is more play in the mud despite being told not to, and sneak to the older kid’s kind of mischievous. And if she is rude, its probably warranted. In that scene, Sansa and Arya werent even interacting and the food throwing was completely unwarranted. I mean, its not even a big deal, but it can be seen as “bullying” and generally something mean, and makes Sansa seem more of an outcast and a target than Arya (which is NOT the case). And they also cut out the part Sansa played in their relationship (horseface, “ugly as hodor”, “they should have killed you instead of Lady”) in order to make Sansa more likable. So in response to your question, kind of but its more complicated (?) than that. 

I actually saw a post (i think it was by gendrie or someone else) that explained this quite well. At least, in more comprehensive way than me. If i find it, i will send it your way.

I am going to assume you mean the food throwing scene in the first episode. In which, sort of. But real problem is that they changed the actual dynamic of Arya and her role and relationships in the stark family. You can see that in the bow scene as well, with arya shooting the bow and everybody laughing and kind of being supportive? In the books, Catelyn would have been furious and would have dragged her right back to Septa Mordane, and Ned wouldnt be approving at all (despite how much he loves Arya, he is still a traditional man with a traditional mindset and a young noble girl with a bow without permission is a big no no.) This is actually very important because the whole concept is that despite how wild Arya is, it’s not approved by anyone and she is expected to behave in a certain way  and it plays a very important part in her characterisation (her self-consciousness, her feeling of being an outcast, her need to belong, her lack of self-confidence and self-worth). The same thing happens in the food scene. Arya throws food at her old sister, in a feast filled with the noble men and the royal family, during a royal visit and seconds after her sister just spoke with queen, is so unrealistic. It’s supposed to be this sweet family moment where we see Arya being mischievous, and show how everyone finds it funny, but in the books, Arya first wouldnt dare (girl might not be one for rules but she at least tries to behave herself, especially when she knows her butt is going to be handed to her if she doesnt). And Arya really isnt that kind of person. She is more play in the mud despite being told not to, and sneak to the older kid’s kind of mischievous. And if she is rude, its probably warranted. In that scene, Sansa and Arya werent even interacting and the food throwing was completely unwarranted. I mean, its not even a big deal, but it can be seen as “bullying” and generally something mean, and makes Sansa seem more of an outcast and a target than Arya (which is NOT the case). And they also cut out the part Sansa played in their relationship (horseface, “ugly as hodor”, “they should have killed you instead of Lady”) in order to make Sansa more likable. So in response to your question, kind of but its more complicated (?) than that. 

I actually saw a post (i think it was by gendrie or someone else) that explained this quite well. At least, in more comprehensive way than me. If i find it, i will send it your way.
trail.content:
I am going to assume you mean the food throwing scene in the first episode. In which, sort of. But real problem is that they changed the actual dynamic of Arya and her role and relationships in the stark family. You can see that in the bow scene as well, with arya shooting the bow and everybody laughing and kind of being supportive? In the books, Catelyn would have been furious and would have dragged her right back to Septa Mordane, and Ned wouldnt be approving at all (despite how much he loves Arya, he is still a traditional man with a traditional mindset and a young noble girl with a bow without permission is a big no no.) This is actually very important because the whole concept is that despite how wild Arya is, it’s not approved by anyone and she is expected to behave in a certain way  and it plays a very important part in her characterisation (her self-consciousness, her feeling of being an outcast, her need to belong, her lack of self-confidence and self-worth). The same thing happens in the food scene. Arya throws food at her old sister, in a feast filled with the noble men and the royal family, during a royal visit and seconds after her sister just spoke with queen, is so unrealistic. It’s supposed to be this sweet family moment where we see Arya being mischievous, and show how everyone finds it funny, but in the books, Arya first wouldnt dare (girl might not be one for rules but she at least tries to behave herself, especially when she knows her butt is going to be handed to her if she doesnt). And Arya really isnt that kind of person. She is more play in the mud despite being told not to, and sneak to the older kid’s kind of mischievous. And if she is rude, its probably warranted. In that scene, Sansa and Arya werent even interacting and the food throwing was completely unwarranted. I mean, its not even a big deal, but it can be seen as “bullying” and generally something mean, and makes Sansa seem more of an outcast and a target than Arya (which is NOT the case). And they also cut out the part Sansa played in their relationship (horseface, “ugly as hodor”, “they should have killed you instead of Lady”) in order to make Sansa more likable. So in response to your question, kind of but its more complicated (?) than that. 

I actually saw a post (i think it was by gendrie or someone else) that explained this quite well. At least, in more comprehensive way than me. If i find it, i will send it your way.

blog.name: kallypsowrites
blog.title: Kallypso Thoughts
blog.description: Welcome to the messy mind of an author, English teacher and maybe an adult. I post writing stuff sometimes. Mostly I reblog memes

summary: Wrote a big Arya and Sansa conversation for a fanfic and remembered how salty I am that D&D decided to pit them against each...
body: Wrote a big Arya and Sansa conversation for a fanfic and remembered how salty I am that D&D decided to pit them against each other for cheap drama after all they’ve been through. And yeah, even if you choose to read it as “they were pretending the whole time” we know that’s not what D&D intended cause of that stupid deleted scene. Anyway, Arya and Sansa better be ride-or-die in the last season.
